;;;;您正在阅读美食场景时事通讯，海伦·罗斯纳 (Helen Rosner) 的关于吃什么、在哪里以及如何吃的指南。;注册即可在您的收件箱中接收它。 ;;;;
;
;

;一家特定的餐厅、一个特定的市场、一份精致的三明治——无论是什么让您来到亚瑟大道，东 187 街两个街区的延伸段位于布朗克斯区中心，以该行政区的“小意大利”而闻名，真正吸引人的是整个区域。如果不是完全不可能，那么快速进出是不明智的——只在一家企业外出，而忽略了周围丰富的食物和饮料。也许您会来多米尼克餐厅 (Dominick’s) 吃斯卡帕里埃罗 (scarpariello)，或者马里奥餐厅 (Mario’s) 吃扇贝，或者卡拉布里亚猪肉店 (Calabria Pork Store) 的一束香肠，但如果不去那里，那就浪费了机会去 Morrone Pastry 买一盒佛罗伦萨面包，或者去 Casa Della Mozzarella 买一份 Alla Phil 夏巴塔面包当午餐。

;
;;
;

;在我看来，如果没有在街上的其中一个车站停下来，该地区的旅行就不完整。户外贝类摊位上的决斗——尤其是在秋天，当空气有点太冷时，在户外感觉就像一种享受。两家仿制的生鲜酒吧，一家位于亚瑟大道东侧的科森扎鱼市场外，另一家位于街对面、街区稍远的 Randazzo's Seafood 店外，您可以在这里订购各种去壳的贝类，然后将它们吃掉站在人行道上的一分钟。撬开牡蛎或蛤蜊并将其从壳中吸出来，不可避免地带有一些原始的味道——没有办法在美学上精炼这种行为本质上的野性。人类肉食性的所有常见中介都不存在：没有屠宰，没有屠宰，没有烹饪。这真是太有趣了，一种仪式感，一种纯粹感觉的时刻。一位穿着大衣、头戴软呢帽的白发绅士，与一位穿着厚底运动鞋的二十多岁的时尚少女、一位穿着迷彩夹克的十一岁男孩和一位中年美食作家并肩扔下十几个蛤蜊：我们是动物吃动物，在街道中央，在布朗克斯。

;
;
;

;人们对他们选择的亚瑟大道商店抱有强烈的忠诚度，主要是基于怀旧之情和难以定义的价值与食品商的个人关系。我不会告诉你科森扎餐厅或兰达佐餐厅哪个更好——事实是，你可以在这两家餐厅吃到一小块美味的鲑鱼或一大堆新鲜的鱿鱼。两者均自 1900 世纪初开始投入使用。两者都拥有一种高效高效的氛围；两者都吸引着热情的人群前往其内部出售的远洋奇观和外部令人惊叹的零装饰原始酒吧。在科森扎，商店橱窗外装满冰块的长凳上陈列着成堆的双壳类动物：前门左边是去壳的蛤蜊（多汁的中型樱桃核，每颗 50 美元，一打 15 美元），右边是牡蛎。在最近的一次访问中，阵容包括来自新不伦瑞克省的 Beau Soleils 和来自马萨诸塞州的 Wellfleets，每人售价 2.99 美元；长岛海湾 (Long Island Sound) 的蓝点 (Blue Point)，售价 2.50 美元；还有来自加州洪堡湾的熊本啤酒，价格高达每份 3.99 美元。这里有一系列的调料和辣酱，包括令人垂涎欲滴的自制木犀草，牡蛎味道鲜美，是盐水和丰富性的交响曲，尤其是蓝点牡蛎，像咸黄油一样温和浓郁，还有熊本的桃子甜味。但我很难克服餐厅级别的定价。站着吃东西的体验令人心旷神怡、超凡脱俗。交出我的信用卡就像是重回地球。

;
;;
;

;沿着街区，街对面，Randazzo's（与羊头湾的同名餐厅没有商业关系，尽管业主是远房表兄弟） ），人行道上的原始酒吧也提供了类似的主张，但空气中多了一点粗犷的气息。当天的产品就放在店外的冰上——但在这里存放在冷藏箱中，而不是整齐地排列起来展示——而且有一个不锈钢台面，而不是像科森扎那样，是一个品牌乙烯基大帐篷。当然，还有蛤蜊，一打十五美元，还有令人兴奋的蛏子，长方形的贝壳里藏着多汁的软体动物，味道比传统的同类更微妙。那里只提供两种牡蛎——蓝点牡蛎（Blue Points），具有浓郁的酒味和青草味，味道鲜美；还有那些黄油味的Beau Soleil牡蛎——每种牡蛎售价两美元。这个价格可以让一个人订购一打，也许之后再订购一打，看看她能把这东西带到多远。和在科森扎 (Cosenza) 一样，你可以站在柜台前，一边剥壳一边啜饮它们，或者，相当诱人地，坐在人行道上靠着另一个商店橱窗的一张折叠椅上，观察来来往往的人流，也许还可以喝上一口。装在小塑料杯里的廉价白葡萄酒神秘地出现在你面前的牌桌上。挤柠檬，沾上辣酱，吞下。 ♦

;“如果那玩意不起作用，我就不穿上个月我们交谈时，导演兼编剧乔治·C·沃尔夫 (George C. Wolfe) 告诉我。他谈论的是童年的包袱，以及他早年在一个偏僻的南方小镇生活的后果，但他也可能很容易谈论他的艺术态度。沃尔夫，六十九岁，美国戏剧界的泰斗，他充满活力地编写和导演戏剧和电影，感觉像是不受义务束缚的自由的产物。从他的作品来看，他似乎总是很开心。

;

;八月，在玛莎葡萄园非裔美国电影节上，我在观众席上看到沃尔夫穿着沙色西装和运动鞋，与 MSNBC 记者乔纳森·卡普哈特 (Jonathan Capehart) 谈论了他的新片《鲁斯汀》(Rustin)，该片以伟大但不太知名的民权领袖贝亚德·鲁斯汀 (Bayard Rustin) 为主题。在舞台上，沃尔夫轻松地坐在椅子上，就像朋友客厅里的双人沙发一样。他满怀自我接纳，在播放电影片段时微笑着，显然对结果感到满意，并将他的答案锐化成俏皮话，他知道这些俏皮话会引起卡普哈特和观众的笑声。

;

;沃尔夫是一个美国表演艺术界的泽利格。他出生于肯塔基州法兰克福，早年凭借《有色人种博物馆》和音乐剧《天堂！》等戏剧赢得了作家的赞誉。他的第一部热门作品是《Jelly's Last Jam》，这是一部关于爵士钢琴家兼乐队领队 Jelly Roll Morton 的音乐剧。那部早期的作品充满了尖刻的智慧和一种疯狂的、略带做作的智慧——这是沃尔夫此后风格的标志。与此同时，这位不安分的多才多艺的人——当然是多才多艺的，也许是因为他早期在音乐剧方面的学术训练——作为戏剧导演获得了更大的声誉。他执导了;托尼·库什纳;的划时代作品《;天使在美国;”，库什纳的音乐剧“卡罗琳，或改变”，以及;Suzan-Lori Parks; 的普利策奖获奖杰作“Topdog/Underdog”。沃尔夫担任公共剧院的艺术总监后，创作并导演了流行音乐剧“Bring in 'da Noise, Bring in 'da Funk”。

;

;2004年，沃尔夫开始了另一个平行的职业生涯，作为一名电影导演，他从改编自鲁本·圣地亚哥-哈德森同名自传剧的《拉克瓦纳布鲁斯》开始。从那时起，他执导了《亨利埃塔·拉克斯的不朽生命》和《;Ma Rainey 的 Black Bottom;”，经常为媒介带来节奏、热情、表演技巧和强度，这些似乎是从他的初恋音乐剧中借来的。< /p>;

;他的新电影讲述了;从拉斯汀（由神秘的科尔曼·多明戈饰演）的角度来看华盛顿游行;，他构思了这次游行并将其组织到最细微的细节。这部电影的基调令人惊讶地轻松——它常常让人感觉像是一个雀跃的故事，而不是这个国家历史上最庄严的公民事件之一。它以一个长而充满活力的画面开头，介绍了广泛的历史人物，包括国会议员亚当·克莱顿·鲍威尔（杰弗里·赖特饰）和民权活动家菲利普·伦道夫（格林·图尔曼饰）和罗伊·威尔金斯（克里斯·威尔金斯饰）。洛克），并以马丁·路德·金（阿米尔·阿米恩饰）对拉斯汀的暂时背叛而达到顶峰——拉斯汀因性取向而被其他几位领导人视为该运动的累赘。 《Rustin》是一部着迷于组织和过程的电影，对诸如种族平等大会 (;CORE;) 等机构的运作感兴趣，因为它处于个人人物投下的长长的阴影中，例如饰演 Rustin、King 和 Ella Baker（奥德拉·麦克唐纳）。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;< /div>;
;

;你可能会认为“Rustin”是沃尔夫数十年职业生涯中许多爱好和知识潮流的结合——民权运动及其来世、同性恋经历以及帮助它生存的伪装，一个计划如何几乎音乐般地组合在一起，并在一场盛大的表演中达到高潮。我和沃尔夫谈论了这部电影、他成长的轮廓，以及如何在娱乐和艺术世界中继续前进。为了清晰和长度，我们的对话已经过编辑。

;
;
;

;;观看“Rustin”时，我开始思考你与传记叙事的关系，回到《果冻的最后果酱》。这是最喜欢的形式吗？你是如何处理我们所说的传记片，并按照生命的时间线进行创作的？;

;

;我讨厌传记片的概念。对我来说，戏剧是关于想法的。因此，在《果冻的最后果酱》中，我对这样一个想法很感兴趣：一个在文化和行为上似乎都是南方人、黑人的人不断地说：“我的祖先直接来自法国海岸。”这种矛盾让我感到惊讶，我想对此进行探索。我越深入这个世界，我对探索新奥尔良就越感兴趣。杰利·罗尔·莫顿 (Jelly Roll Morton) 的职业生涯非常有趣，因为他从南方来到芝加哥，但当他到达纽约时，路易斯·阿姆斯特朗 (Louis Armstrong) 也到了，所以新奥尔良最好的部分已经融入到了场景中。我对出现在这座城市却事业起步晚的人很感兴趣。这个人变成了一个想法。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;和 Bayard 一起，我对 1963 年的夏天着迷。三个月后，肯尼迪去世了。到了 64 或 65 年，;CORE; 变成了 ;CORE; East，并且变得更加激进。因此，从历史上看，存在这样一个门口，非暴力将受到质疑。这个国家将会变得更加暴力。然后就有了这位才华横溢的组织者，他是同性恋——在 1963 年他是同性恋，毫无歉意——他在八周内组织了这次游行。这部电影让我有机会不仅生活在角色内部，而且生活在这个时期，并探索这个国家团结在一起的重大事件。它聚集在一起，然后在很长一段时间内发生破裂。这对我来说很有趣。另外，贝亚德只是一个非凡的案例研究。

;

;我变得对人着迷。我很迷恋艾拉·贝克，所以我想，让我把她放在这里并确保她很重要。鲁比·多丽丝（Ruby Doris）——我对她很着迷——也是民权运动中的人物，她去了斯佩尔曼学校，然后被开除，并且是;SNCC;的重要人物，最后她有了一个孩子成为一名黑人民族主义者，并在她二十六岁时去世。我开始着迷于某些人的生活，以及他们在如此短的时间内所取得的辉煌。

;
;
;

;;你的想法之间是否存在任何紧张关系？试图提出人们有时希望从有关历史人物的电影中得到的东西——也许是一种真实感，就好像他们从历史书中得到了一小段页面一样？;

;

;我从纽约大学获得了双硕士学位，一个是戏剧写作，一个是音乐剧，每天项目中的其他人都会说，“我喜欢那个角色吗？这个角色可爱吗？”我说：“他他妈就是个人类。”这些品质将尽我所能在旅途中延续，因此我对这种“讨人喜欢”的方程式感到厌恶——尽管我认为贝亚德·鲁斯汀是一个非常讨人喜欢的人。因为，如果角色是人，他们就更像我，也更像我们。这就是为什么我喜欢马丁·路德·金的第一个场景，因为他做了一件糟糕的事情：他背叛了他的亲密朋友。他后来救赎了自己，但我喜欢这一切——因为那时他们就是人。我可以看着它，然后想，让我找到进入这个故事的方式，如果他们能克服他们的狗屎，我也能。纪念碑的事情——我对此不感兴趣。

;

;;在这部电影中，你有一个明显有魅力的人，人们蜂拥而至，他也蜂拥而至其他人，但你确实看到了他的缺点总是回到前台。作为一名导演，您如何引导像科尔曼·多明戈这样的演员走过这条弧线？是否关注档案内容，拉斯汀实际上是如何移动和说话的？你依赖日记吗？;

;

;科尔曼踏上了自己的旅程。他自己进行了技术研究。就像，贝亚德是男高音，科尔曼是男中音，所以他对自己的演讲进行了所有调整。然后，工作就发生在人际动态中——比如他和艾拉·贝克之间的动态。这里的权力动态是什么？菲利普·伦道夫是谁？此时此刻，马丁·路德·金是谁？你觉得你比他聪明吗？

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;
;
;
;
;

;拍摄前我会排练两周，拍摄前每天都会排练我有一个排练期。我清理了整个场景，演员和我开始探索场景的内容——阻止它并做所有这些事情，但也创建一个安全结构，以便演员能够承受最大的脆弱性。你会了解角色的真实情况以及他们所做的所有工作，然后你坐在一张桌子旁，看着科尔曼·多明戈，以及权力动态和变化。她在推动什么？她说了什么别人不能说的话？这有什么影响？您正在暴露角色，因此，当某个紧张时刻发生时，演员会以惊人的方式接受它，而您正在观看一个自发的时刻。

;
;
;

;我的赞歌之一是，观众可以分辨出演员何时在做一些专门为这部电影而发现的事情，以及何时从另一部电影中回收一些垃圾。我们的目标是制作一部充满无尽赤裸裸发现的电影。

;

;;并不是每个电影导演都像您一样专注于排练。这是来自你的戏剧背景吗？;

;

;这是其中的一部分。但这也是你如何与演员一起发展词汇的方式——这也是你如何让他们踏上旅程的方式。你问问题。有时我问问题不是为了得到答案，而是为了看看演员在他们的过程中处于什么位置。当我们每天表演《雷尼妈妈的黑屁股》时，查德维克·博斯曼每天都会走到我面前说：“感谢上帝，我们进行了两周的排练。”这是一个扎根的时期，然后就会让位于未知的、脆弱的、令人惊讶的事情。

;

;梅丽尔·斯特里普告诉我，当她表演《苏菲的选择》时，他们每天早上都会排练，然后他们下午就去拍它给演员一种指挥感，而这种指挥使他们能够自由地面对素材和角色的脆弱性。因此，这不是模仿戏剧的问题，我认为，这是一个精心设计场景的过程，使出色的作品成为可能。那些不能移植到屏幕上的东西？;

;

;我把这一切都简化为讲故事。有时我讲一个故事，最后故事发生在一座古老的维多利亚式建筑中，人们坐得太近，有时有一台小机器记录着一切。亲密的方程式，以及你捕捉到这种亲密的程度，各不相同，但你和演员们总是在寻找绝对的真相。这就是你的使命，我认为这超越了一切。

;

;在戏剧排练中，你正在帮助演员锻炼肌肉，这样你作为导演就变得无关紧要，这样他们每天晚上都可以出去并负责自己的表演。在电影中，你试图捕捉尽可能多的不同时刻，以及这些时刻的尽可能多的变化，这样当你最终进入剪辑室时，你就有了可以挖掘的大量词汇，并且可以分辨你想讲的故事。这有意义吗？

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;< /div>;
;

;;确实如此。;

;
;
;

;;我一直认为您的电影生涯特别依赖于您在音乐剧方面的经验。你的电影不仅在某种程度上经常与音乐有关，而且其中的节奏、节奏和动态也是音乐性的。在《鲁斯汀》中，人们唱着自由之歌，这些场景有一个音乐逻辑。当然，贝亚德·鲁斯汀也录制了自己的音乐。您如何看待这些时刻？;

;

;导演音乐剧培养了我拍电影的精神力量。

;

;;真的吗？;;

;音乐剧是野兽。他们是野兽。电视节目“;M;*;A;*;S;*;H;”的联合编剧拉里·格尔巴特 (Larry Gelbart) 说道， “如果希特勒还活着，我希望他能带着音乐剧出城。”当你在预览时，你正在管理一个城镇；当你在预览时，你正在管理一个城镇。然后你停下来，人群进来，他们要么充满敌意，要么很兴奋，这取决于你所做的工作的质量。有时，如果你巧妙地改变某件事，就会改变他们的看法。这是一个很好的训练场，可以培养人们对材料以及什么有效、什么无效的分析能力。

;

;在很早的时候，在与布兰福德·马萨利斯交谈时，我就设想了这个 1963 年的爵士四重奏。 。对我来说，爵士乐除了打响指之外，还很理智，而且我正在和非常聪明的男人和女人打交道。我希望观众确切地知道他们在哪里，并捕捉到我正在与一个黑人知识分子打交道——在很多方面，不仅仅是——一个黑人知识分子。我希望他们能够理解那种节奏。另外，有了这个四重奏（结果不是四重奏，它比四重奏大得多），你将拥有主要独奏者贝亚德。

;

;

;

;;鲍威尔认为他应该负责。;;

;

;

;

;;What was the locus of community for you, growing up? Was it a church environment?;

;It was any number of things—the school, the church, the neighborhood. My grandmother lived down the street, and she was a ferocious, protective figure, and very commanding. I still have, to this day, a recording, “Great Moments in Negro History.” All of that was fortification, so that the limitations that were thrust upon us never penetrated past a force field of adults and community and church and relatives, so that you dreamed and you believed and you wanted to achieve, and you felt a responsibility to contribute, and you did all those things, and there was not any equation of racial inferiority at play, at all, ever.

;

I don't feel equipped to offer forth a solution, but it's a really interesting time that all these regional theatres, post-;COVID;, are going through. ;Pacifica, California, just south of San Francisco, is the kind of beachfront community that longtime residents compare to Heaven. One of its streets is called Paradise Drive; local fishermen brag that Pacifica Pier is among the state's best places to catch salmon, striped bass, and crab. Every few years, a ;superbloom; blankets the coast with golden wildflowers. When the sun cuts through the region's famous fog, the sky sometimes glows, as in a Turner painting.

;

;Some of Pacifica's most dramatic views could be found on Esplanade Drive, where mid-century developers built bungalows on top of a cliff. For almost fifty years, residents gazed out from their back yards to see whales splashing in the Pacific. Then, in 1998, a group of homeowners gathered to say goodbye. “I cannot express how spectacular it has been living here,” one of them, Joe Parker, said at the time. “I've seen dolphins out there. I recognize all the seabirds.” Beverly Axelrod, who had spent fourteen years on Esplanade Drive, recalled how her ocean view had “healed everything.” But then a series of vicious storms, fuelled in part by the warm waters of El Niño, had washed away more than thirty feet of the cliff beneath their homes. Workers had to saw Axelrod's house in half to prevent it from falling into the sea. Ken Lajoie, a local geologist, said that, even after the wind and waves abated, more of the cliff would crumble. The city ultimately condemned seven houses to be bulldozed. One woman was now paying the mortgage on a house that didn't exist; Axelrod compared the demolition to “being at the bedside of somebody who's dying.”

;

;In the nineteen-eighties, Pacifica had fortified parts of its shore with a twenty-foot-tall concrete seawall. It had also coated some areas with loose rock, known as riprap. After the storms of 1998, the city shored up its defenses again; state and federal agencies gave Pacifica $1.5 million to pile riprap at the base of the cliff. The city thought of its investments as forward-thinking, in light of climate change. But Lajoie warned that riprap seawalls usually fail. “Stop building structures along eroding coastlines,” he told a San Francisco ;Chronicle; reporter, in 2001. “Prevent future construction of seawalls of any type.”

;

;Lajoie was right: the seawall beneath Esplanade Drive did not stop the sea. In 2010, part of the cliff fell out from under an apartment building, which had to be abandoned and then torn down. By 2018, only one house remained on a portion of the street that overlooked the cliff. After its patio tumbled off the edge, the city government bought the house and demolished it. Around that time, the mayor of Pacifica, John Keener, started talking about adapting to rising seas, and even about “managed retreat.” Instead of trying to fortify the shore forever, he suggested, residents might consider moving out of harm's way.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Most people, understandably, don't want to abandon their homes. In a new book, “;California Against the Sea: Visions for Our Vanishing Coastline;” (Heyday), Rosanna Xia, an environmental reporter at the Los Angeles ;Times;, visits Pacifica and encounters a sign that reads “;NO MANAGED RETREAT;.” At a city-council meeting, a father of three stands up and declares, “It's a war with the sea. We may win, we may lose, but we should never give up the ground unnecessarily.” Keener was voted out of office, in large part by residents calling for stronger coastal protections. “The city fell asleep and should've seawalled all this decades earlier,” one man told Xia.

;

;Pacifica embodies one of the central disagreements about rising seas. Fight or flight? Stay or go? Flight can seem unimaginable. But, if we try to fight the ocean with rock and concrete, it will cost us—and it may not work. Pacifica currently plans to borrow tens of millions of dollars to reinforce its seawall. Writing for a community blog, Gregg Dieguez, a critic of this plan, objected not just to its price but to the “moral hazard” it would create: by forestalling erosion, the seawall might only encourage more people to live in risky places. “Once sea level rise gets here, it's never going away, at least not for thousands of years,” Dieguez wrote. Meanwhile, he noted, only one per cent of the homes in Pacifica were at risk. “You will have to decide, as a group, whether paying to hold back the tides is a good use of your precious money,” he concluded. It's a question many more of us will soon be asking. When do seawalls make sense? And when is it better to give in to the tides?

;

;The oldest known seawall was built around 5000 BC, after a period of warming that melted glaciers and lifted the Mediterranean by a staggering twenty-six feet. A Stone Age community, living near a beach in present-day Israel, tried to ward off the sea with a wall of three-foot-tall boulders about the length of a football field. But, in the millennia that followed, the Mediterranean rose even more. Archeologists ultimately discovered the stones on the seafloor, under ten feet of water. The site, they wrote, was “ominously relevant” to our time. Other excavations have turned up ancient coastal fortifications in places like Lebanon and Egypt. Ancient Roman ports used a kind of concrete that grew stronger in contact with water.

;

;In the war with the sea, the Dutch have probably spent the longest in the trenches. When Pliny the Elder visited the Low Countries in 47 AD, he compared the people he met to marooned sailors living on artificial mounds of mud; by the early Middle Ages, locals started to build a seawall. A 1948 book by a Dutch engineer, “;Dredge, Drain, Reclaim: The Art of a Nation;,” describes the wall as a major victory in an existential struggle. “Formerly the terrible evils of the sea, the storm floods and the more terrible marine erosion, had to be endured, but now the fight began to throw the sea out of the country; a fight not yet ended and a fight for to be or not to be,” he wrote. But the walls had a side effect. They locked the land into place, trading in a dynamic shoreline for one that could not adapt as easily, and that would need to be defended forever.

;
;
;

;There are many kinds of coastal protection. Some of the most effective are entirely natural. Marshes, mangroves, and even sandy beaches can absorb the destructive power of waves, helping to soak up water and energy that would otherwise wreak havoc. Engineers can fortify a shoreline by replenishing lost sand, or by adding rock, wood, or concrete. It's also possible to augment the shore. A rock pile that parallels the coast, shielding the beach from waves, is called a breakwater. A pile that juts out to sea, trapping sand on one side, is called a groin. All of these measures are already widely used on coastlines around the world.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Hard seawalls may be the bluntest instrument in coastal engineering. Typically, they are made from concrete, stone, wood, or metal, and rise vertically from the shore. But a wave that strikes a seawall never breaks and dissipates, as it would on a beach; instead, it bounces off like an echo, its destructive force intact. In the end, the flow of water and sediment is a zero-sum game. For a wave to spare one place, it has to strike another; for sand to accumulate somewhere, it has to wash away from somewhere else.

;
;
;

;According to the sociologist Summer Gray, seawalls are less a practical solution than a product of technocratic ideology—one that colonial powers have exported around the world. For all their potential benefits, seawalls “harm the environment, shift vulnerability downstream, lead to the disappearance of the beach, and create cycles of dependency,” she writes in her new book, “;In the Shadow of the Seawall;” (University of California Press). In one meticulous chapter, Gray recounts how the Dutch West India Company settled the low-lying coast of Guyana, in South America. Planters enslaved Africans, who were forced to build seawalls and then to cultivate sugarcane. The people of Guyana eventually came to see their aging seawalls as a necessity; there was now significant development on low-lying land. When storms surge over our protections, we tend to wonder why they weren't higher, rather than questioning the logic of living by the sea.

;

;In the nineteenth century, Gray writes, engineers started to consider the unintended consequences of fortifications. In 1899, Edward Case, the keeper of the Dymchurch wall, which protects Romney Marsh, in southern England, noted that, when the “Lords of the Marsh” built their manors in the muck, they locked themselves into centuries of dependence on the wall. “But for the value of the land at stake . 。 。 the struggle must have been abandoned,” Case observed. After waves washed away sediment in front of the wall, he made a counterintuitive argument: seawalls can contribute to the erosion they are supposed to prevent. At the base of a seawall, the constant churn of water stirs up sediment; that sediment is then swept back to sea. This phenomenon is now known as scour. Sometimes the water erodes so much sand that it causes walls to collapse.

;

;“;Over the Seawall: Tsunamis, Cyclones, Drought, and the Delusion of Controlling Nature;” (Island Press), by the journalist Stephen Robert Miller, tells a story of double-edged engineering in Bangladesh, where the flow of water and sediment creates a rich and ever-changing agricultural zone. The region “is not so much a world pestered by water as one defined by it,” Miller writes. But, when the British colonized Bangladesh, they fractured the waterscape with embankments, farms, and railroads; after they departed, international development workers went a step further, walling off a hundred and three low-lying islands that they called ;polders;, using a Dutch word for land that is reclaimed and then fortified. Although these walls protect lives and property, they also draw Bangladeshis to areas that are vulnerable to storm surges, which devastate coastal communities during tropical cyclones. Miller writes of some floods that, paradoxically, killed more people in the places with stronger walls. “The embankments provide only pseudo security,” Dilip Datta, an environmental scientist at Khulna University, tells him. “They work against our best interest.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;When I ran these critiques of coastal protection by Rachel Gittman, a marine ecologist at East Carolina University, she offered another reason to worry about seawalls. Natural habitats already serve as powerful buffers against flooding, she said. They absorb water and energy; this is why marsh and mangrove restoration is often the best way to protect a coast. By contrast, when coastal communities wall off the shoreline, they tend to trap ecosystems between the water and the wall, causing a process called coastal squeeze. “It can be a slow drowning of those habitats,” she told me. When they disappear, we may be more vulnerable than when we started.

;

;Our present dilemma is worse than it needed to be. In 1981, a group of coastal geologists gathered on Skidaway Island, in Georgia, to write a report called “Saving the American Beach.” They warned that rising seas and migration toward the ocean would expose a growing number of people to erosion, flooding, and storms. Saving the shore, they argued, might “involve drastic and unpopular measures such as assuming that buildings adjacent to the beach are temporary or expendable.” By the time a second group of experts met at Skidaway, in 1985, their fears had escalated. “Sea level is rising and the American shoreline is retreating,” they wrote. “We face economic and environmental realities that leave us two choices: (1) plan for a strategic retreat now, or (2) undertake a vastly expensive program of armoring the coastline and, as required, retreating through a series of unpredictable disasters.”

;

;The Skidaway experts were hardly the only ones to foresee our current circumstances. Yet, in the decades since their reports, the number of Americans who live near a coast has almost doubled. In 2018, coastal counties were home to a hundred and twenty-eight million people, or forty per cent of US residents. Today, about fourteen per cent of the coast is fortified with hard barriers.

;

;Coastal protection is usually treated as a cost-and-benefit problem. The more people and property in a given place, the greater a seawall's benefits. Last year, when the Army Corps of Engineers proposed a vast network of seawalls and gates to shield New York and New Jersey Harbor, it argued that the fifty-three-billion-dollar project was a very good deal: although it “will not totally eliminate flood risks” in the area, it would cost much less than repairing the city after every storm. (Hurricane Sandy caused an estimated nineteen billion dollars in damage in New York City alone.) The densest, wealthiest, and most vulnerable coastal cities—Bangkok, Shanghai, Rio de Janeiro, San Francisco, Miami—are likely to make similar calculations. Yes, a seawall may erode the shore and draw even more people toward the water, but lives and livelihoods are already concentrated there; if a seawall could save them, don't we have to build one? The opposite, presumably, will be true in rural and ecologically fragile places; a seawall might endanger too many species, or wash away too many beaches, or simply protect too little, to justify the costs.

;
;
;

;Such calculations, however, leave a lot out. Industrialized societies have never been good at valuing the nonhuman (the coastal ecosystems that seawalls squeeze out) or the intangible (the cultural, historical, or spiritual value of a place). The cost-benefit equation doesn't account for moral hazard, either. Seawalls are supposed to shield us from risk, but, if they draw people and property to the shore, they might wind up exposing more of us to it. Money also tends to protect money. Do we want to live in a world where only the wealthy can afford seawalls, and everyone else must retreat or risk drowning?

;

;Gray, the sociologist, is wary of managed retreat, too. “Staying in place on a warming planet is an inherently unequal struggle,” she writes. She notes that those least able to fight the pressure to relocate—for example, residents of the Maldives, where she sets half of her book—may be urged to move. “Resilience planners often ask vulnerable populations to transform themselves in drastic ways that are not asked of 'nonvulnerable' populations,” she writes. Coastal communities that can't afford seawalls could be left with no good options. Gray never fully unties this knot; she ultimately dedicates her book to “the frontline communities who stay and fight.”

;

;If our math is wrong, what could right it? In an era of rising seas, we are primed to think of coastal protections as prudent. Given their unintended consequences, however, we should be wary of their risks and skeptical of their benefits. Instead of building as many walls as we can, we should build as few as we need to—and only when they protect what matters most. This last notion, of what matters most, is a question, not an answer. Seawalls are expensive, and unfairness will be one of their heaviest costs.

;

;In “California Against the Sea,” Xia, the environmental reporter, writes about the difficult realities of trying to incorporate fairness into our tally of costs and benefits. In the Southern California city of Laguna Beach, Xia examines a picturesque public shoreline that separates mansions from the sea. Here, in 2015, a wealthy couple bought an aging waterfront home; they remodelled it into a stone-and-glass fortress and shored up a private seawall at its base. In a sense, they were weighing the costs and benefits of climate adaptation—but only for themselves. A neighbor soon complained to the California Coastal Commission that the wall was a threat to the beach. It was now up to the commission to decide if the wall was allowed.

;

;Xia tracks down Orrin Pilkey, a co-author of the Skidaway reports who has become known for his single-minded insistence on managed retreat, to ask him for his opinion. He argues that the neighbor was right to worry. A private seawall can deflect waves toward neighboring houses, forcing them to erect walls of their own—a domino effect in reverse. “If one homeowner wins, the whole state loses,” Pilkey tells her. “If you give up the fight on one location, then you're going to have to give up eventually on all locations.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The commission seemed to agree: it declared the wall illegal, ordered it torn down, and fined the couple a million dollars for remodelling a coastal house without its permission. It also resolved to oppose new seawalls up and down the coast, with few exceptions. “Seawalls damage beaches by preventing sand from reaching the beach, which eventually causes beaches to shrink until they disappear,” the commission said in a release. “In an era of sea level rise, the long-term effect of sea walls is to temporarily protect the property behind them, at the permanent expense of public sandy beach space.”

;

;In theory, a moratorium on residential seawalls is itself a kind of coastal squeeze, meant to encourage relocation. This is a complicated position to take, but it reflects a complicated reality. The Coastal Commission seemed to be saying that coastal Californians were free to stay until the sea came for their homes—as long as they did not try to stop it from doing so. If you can't retreat behind a wall, you might retreat to a landlocked town that doesn't need one. In practice, however, many homeowners would rather dig in for a fight. The Laguna Beach family took the commission to court, and, when Xia finished her book, the rogue seawall was still standing.

;

;On a windy evening in August, I biked to a park in lower Manhattan to meet Yuki Miura, a soft-spoken researcher who has modelled the flooding that a hurricane would inflict on Manhattan. Miura, who grew up in Tokyo, told me that a mega-storm will come eventually. In fact, “it already happened,” she said. The storm surge from Hurricane Sandy, in 2012, peaked at nearly fourteen feet, inundating hundreds of city blocks. “Whenever I run the model, there are certain areas that pretty much always get flooded,” Miura told me. We were standing in one of them.

;

;We walked together toward the East River until we came to a hulking concrete wall, which had been built so recently that it was still wrapped in plastic. Miura told me that, when she visited this area a couple of years ago, as a doctoral student in civil engineering at Columbia University, the lower-Manhattan seawall, known as the ;BIG; U, was only a proposal. “It didn't exist at all,” she said. She was happy that, at least in this one place, the city had started to fortify the shore.

;
;
;

;To gain access to the waterfront, we walked through a truck-size gap in the wall, passing a wheeled floodgate that looked like a narrow train car. Then we forded a stream of after-work joggers and came to a little cliff of concrete by the river. On the other side of a metal railing, the wake from passing ferries lapped at New York's fortified shoreline.

;

;When the next storm comes, Miura told me, the river will start to climb—slowly, more like a rising tide than a tsunami. If a strong hurricane strikes when the tide is already high, “this area would be underwater,” she said. The seawall behind us, which rose sixteen feet above sea level, was tall enough to limit—though not eliminate—coastal flooding from the biggest possible hurricanes. But Miura warned that, if a storm strikes while the wall is under construction, before it protects the entirety of lower Manhattan, then water will find the unprotected areas, flow behind the wall, and fester there. So far, only a small portion of the ;BIG; U has been built.

;

;I asked Miura whether, instead of building walls that could anchor people along the coast, New Yorkers should think about moving away from the shore. “Managed retreat might be a good option in different regions,” she told me. “It's very hard to imagine here.” Manhattan is home to 1.6 million people and trillions of dollars of coastal infrastructure. Once you've built skyscrapers and hospitals and highways along the water, just a few feet above sea level, it's hard to imagine any path into the future that leaves so much of value behind.

;

;Talking to Miura, I thought about all of the choices that had led to this moment. We are fortifying the shore in part because we burned fossil fuels; we burned fossil fuels because we believed that some other place, or some later generation, would bear the consequences. In this sense, the story of seawalls and their downsides mirrors the larger story of the climate crisis. “We need to solve the problem from the bottom,” Miura told me. Until we do the hard, collective work of slashing emissions, the planet will keep getting hotter, the water will keep rising, and the storms will keep getting worse.

;

;As the sun set, Miura and I looked out across the water. The clouds were turning purple and orange; a few boats drifted by. It was easy to understand why someone would want to live here. Then my eyes came to rest on the apartment blocks and factories that dotted the Queens waterfront—an area that is as densely populated as parts of Manhattan, but where no comparable seawalls have been built. I asked Miura what would happen there. Could the water that would have flooded Manhattan instead end up somewhere else, like Queens?

;

;“It will be shifted, yeah,” Miura told me. “Water has to go somewhere.” ♦

;You could write dozens of obituaries a year for beloved New York restaurants that have shuttered their doors.我最喜欢这座城市的事情之一就是它克服一切困难的再生能力。我们生活在这样一个时刻：维持一家餐馆的运营比以往任何时候都更加困难，更不用说开一家新餐馆了，但总有令人难以置信的新吃饭地点——全球流行病和洪水该死。 In the past few years, as I ate my way through the boroughs, chronicling meals for ;Tables for Two;, the delights seemed inexhaustible.我最近换了一个新角色，这意味着我不再每周撰写专栏（尽管我仍会定期为该杂志撰写有关食品的文章）。作为给读者的临别礼物，我决定列出我所评论过的我最喜欢的地方。很难选择，但我发现了一些特别令人兴奋的刺激。熨斗区的一个古老的犹太午餐柜台，被新主人精心改造，并以某种方式变得更加本质。史泰登岛的一家传统土耳其美食宫殿，前身是一座煎饼屋，值得在交通堵塞的情况下穿过维拉扎诺大桥一游。韩国城一家美食广场深处的一个小面摊，由一位忠诚的女儿和她的母亲经营，她们亲手制作每一盘食物。我在布什威克的一家波斯餐厅喝过最好喝的鸡尾酒，里面加入了橙花水和干石灰。 Here are twenty New York restaurants, among thousands, that I recommend without reservation.

;
;Superiority Burger
;

;;Vegetarian; | ;East Village;

;

;Earlier this year, the chef Brooks Headley relocated his previously tiny veggie-burger joint to the relatively sprawling space in the East Village that, for decades, had housed the Odessa Restaurant. The original ;Superiority Burger; offered just six dishes, plus specials and desserts.所有这些，包括同名汉堡，都是素食；很多都是“不小心成为素食主义者”。一切都弹出了。在最近的访问中，我很高兴地发现海德利一如既往地专注。新增加的内容很少但功能强大。为了向敖德萨的乌克兰传统致敬，这里有一种质感令人兴奋的酿卷心菜，里面填满了糯米、牡蛎和蘑菇，外面裹着酸甜的番茄酱，最后撒上松脆的佛卡夏面包屑。旧菜单的保留包括由藜麦、鹰嘴豆和核桃制成的汉堡； Sloppy Dave（豆腐辣椒、卷洋葱）；烧西兰花沙拉（茄子泥、蜜饯腰果）；还有甜菜配奶油奶酪和椒盐卷饼——一切仍然很棒。 ;;Read the full review »;;

;Laser Wolf
;

;;Israeli; | ;Williamsburg;

;

;On a summer evening at ;Laser Wolf;, a restaurant on the rooftop of the Hoxton hotel, in Williamsburg, a friendly but authoritative woman zipped dutifully from table to table, pausing at each. “我们为日落鼓掌，”她宣布。 “不要恐慌。”一时间，服务似乎停止了。当集体目光落在一览无余的曼哈顿天际线时，尸体向西移动。电话被抽走了。当闪闪发光的球体沉入爱德联合大学钟楼后面时，蓝天融化成金色，戏剧性的光线照亮了棉球云，掌声响起，伴随着欢呼声。在这样的景色下，食物和饮料很容易成为次要的，更不用说完全的欺骗了。 Laser Wolf 餐厅是备受喜爱的费城同名餐厅的分店，由以色列裔美国厨师迈克尔·索罗门诺夫 (Michael Solomonov) 和餐厅老板史蒂夫·库克 (Steve Cook) 经营，这里的环境让人感觉可以忽略不计。 ;;Read the full review »;;

;Great NY Noodletown
;

;;Cantonese; | ;Chinatown;

;
;
;

;The intensely beloved ;Cantonese restaurant; closed for several months in 2022;去年九月，当金属大门终于再次升起时：欣喜若狂。食物和任何人记忆中的一样好——如果不是更好的话。我上次去那里是在 2017 年，当时姜葱捞面、一团又细又卷的滑溜溜的面条，激活了我舌头后部的味蕾，否则我根本不知道那里的味蕾。能重新体会到那种感觉，端上来一碗清香四溢的肉汤，里面充满了像水母一样上下浮动的馄饨，褶皱的肚子里塞满了虾，光滑的皮皮像触手一样拖着，这是多么令人愉快的事。 Among old favorites I found new ones: thick ;e-fu; noodles strewn over a lobster chopped in its shell;陶罐里装满了蛤蜊，用米酒蒸熟，再加上大块的姜和葱，堆在粉丝上。 ;;Read the full review »;;

;Ju Qi

;The most obvious thing to eat at ;Ju Qi;, a restaurant in Tangram, a luxury mall in Flushing, is a bird—a whole Peking duck, carved tableside.首先，厨师以外科医生般的精准度去除一长条涂漆的金色皮肤，将其切成邮票大小的片段；每一个都放在一个方形的馒头上面，最后放上一堆精致的鲟鱼鱼子酱。服务员从看起来像皇家珠宝箱的地方拉出小抽屉，里面装有海鲜、葱、黄瓜火柴、泡菜、哈密瓜，然后演示将肉片和装饰物包裹成从竹子上摘下的煎饼的最佳技术。汽船。这是一次激动人心的戏剧体验，结局盛大：您想要将尸体切成一口大小并炸脆，还是浸入芳香可口的浑浊汤中，配上丝豆腐和嫩蔬菜？我更喜欢后者，但这两种制剂都充分利用了附着在骨头上的珍贵肉和脂肪。 ;;Read the full review »;;

;Even in the best circumstances, a trip to Staten Island from any other borough is a commitment, a decent journey by bridge or boat. ;The menu at this ;Nolita restaurant;, owned by Ann Redding and her husband, Matt Danzer, is partly inspired by the way that Redding's mother, who emigrated from Thailand, adapted her cooking to the US The Thai disco fries come smothered in massaman curry, red onions, peanuts, and coconut cream; breakfast offerings include spectacular egg sandwiches made with roti snugly folded around a soft scramble, American cheese, Thai basil, and either ;sai oua;—a Northern Thai-style curry-seasoned pork sausage—or avocado and bok choy.令人高兴的是，这里的一些菜肴是从 Uncle Boons 移植过来的，这是这对夫妇的第一家更严格的泰式餐厅，他们被迫于 2020 年关闭。我特别高兴能与最高级的泰式炒河粉（又名泰式炒河粉）重聚。 ，并搭配切碎的花生、干虾、生洋葱和生姜，用烤椰子酱包裹在胡椒槟榔叶中。 ;;Read the full review »;;

;I can think of no better summer meal than a bowl of ;naengmyeon;, a cold Korean noodle soup traditionally eaten after a meal of barbecue. ;Noona Noodles;, a stall run by a mother-daughter duo in a food court in Manhattan's Koreatown, offers two varieties: ;mul; and ;bibim;, rebranded as Icy and Icy Spicy.两者的特点是味道浓郁的肉汤，由牛胸肉与新鲜菠萝、亚洲梨、苹果、柠檬、白萝卜和什锦葱一起煮沸而成，并配有大块的冰泥，冰块像雪一样吸收了酸甜可口的液体视锥细胞。每个碗的中心都是一堆细长、耐嚼、光滑的面条，再加上轻微腌制的萝卜、黄瓜和几片牛胸肉。冰辣还包括一层厚厚的辣椒酱，需要搅拌；冰冷的肉汤含量较多，配有粉醋（腌萝卜剩下的）和热芥末，可以增加微妙的味道。 ;;Read the full review »;;

;Earlier this year, Ben Smith, the former editor-in-chief of BuzzFeed News and a onetime New York ;Times; columnist, ;published; a book, titled “;Traffic: Genius, Rivalry, and Delusion in the Billion-Dollar Race to Go Viral;.”它探讨了资金雄厚的新闻和文化网站（其中包括 BuzzFeed News 和《赫芬顿邮报》）的创建以及它们之间的竞争，这些网站始于 2000 年初，当时专业博客圈刚刚起步。 One day after the book's May 2nd release, the ;Times; published a Smith-authored ;guest essay;, titled “We're Watching the End of a Digital Media Age. It All Started with Jezebel.”

;

;Jezebel is an influential feminist Web site that I created in 2007. Smith had devoted an entire chapter of “Traffic” to the story of the site's creation, stumbles, and successes. He was complimentary, calling it “a new kind of cultural politics,” one that built “a community that rejected the old structures of gender and power, and tried to shape new ones.”

;

;One could be forgiven for discerning a slight difference in tone between “Traffic” and the essay that appeared in the ;Times;. Smith's book took a deep look at the impact of a number of Web sites, but his ;Times; essay seemed to make the argument that Jezebel in particular reflected a “remarkable new openness” and “uncontrollable anger” on the Internet. As he put it, “What makes Jezebel feel so relevant now is that it was among the first places to crystallize the powerful forces that would define social media over the next decade: politics and identity.”

;

;I agreed that Jezebel embodied a “remarkable new openness,” and I was flattered by Smith's acknowledgment of the site's continued influence.但他写的一些内容让我犹豫不决。他的文章将该网站定位为一个时代的开始，并在 2016 年唐纳德·特朗普当选时达到顶峰。我不想与它有任何关系。至于“无法控制的愤怒”？ The phrase felt sexist and paternalistic.

;

;I live in Los Angeles, so I wasn't immediately aware of the conversation about the essay. People started texting me around 7 ;AM; PST In the darkness of my cozy bedroom, I took a quick glance at the piece on my phone, admired the accompanying photo of me (it was a good photo, and I can be vain), rolled my eyes at a few of the conclusions, and then went back to bed.

;

;About half an hour later, I was awoken again, this time by a phone call from a friend.网上（即推特）似乎正在酝酿对这篇文章的小规模强烈反对。一些读者认为，史密斯通过将注意力集中在耶洗别身上，将愤怒的文化归咎于女性。我饶有兴趣地读到了这篇文章——毕竟，女性在很多事情上都受到指责，而在其他事情上却没有得到足够的认可——但我也没有精力去回应它。 I placed my phone on my bedside table and pulled the covers back over my head.

;
;
;

;I felt ambivalent.这篇文章激起了一些我无法弄清楚的过去的事情：如果有的话，我可能在网上嘲讽话语的演变中扮演了什么角色。史密斯无意回答这个问题——他的一些语言也许是故意的，有点含糊。但他确实在耶洗别经常好斗的评论者和 Twitter 等社交媒体平台的最终用户之间建立了联系，指责该网站引发了“激烈的在线暴民”。 Jezebel 是在社交媒体广泛采用之前几年创建的，当时人们还在访问博客，然后刷新博客以查看出现了哪些新帖子。 According to Smith, “The unmediated passions of social media took up where it left off.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Anger can be explosive.它可以点燃社会运动，消除关于性、性别、阶级和种族的僵化观念。公平地说，当女性表达这种观点或被指控表达这种观点时，她们很容易（有时甚至是恶毒）受到嘲笑和嘲笑。对于有色人种女性来说也许更是如此，她们不仅要应对性别歧视的比喻，还要应对种族刻板印象以及围绕愤怒和语气的恐吓。 (Both my deputy editor at Jezebel, Dodai Stewart, and I are Black. The widely held assumption that the site was staffed only by white women possibly did us some sort of favor.)

;

;But here's the thing about tone: in many cases, it ;does; matter.尽管我经常在政治上和个人上同意我们的评论者的观点，但他们过分的言辞可能会让我感到疏远。我担心这种言论可能会冒犯新读者，并且会对我们试图影响并将其带入主流的围绕性别政治的新对话有害。是否有“太多”愤怒之类的事情？如果是这样，我是谁来确定什么是“太多”？ I felt torn, so I kept these questions mostly to myself.

;

;When Jezebel launched, I was thirty-three, about to turn thirty-four.促成该网站创建的事件之前已被多次提及。简而言之：由于对美国女性媒体的现状感到失望，我获得了千载难逢的机会来创建和监督一个女性媒体实体——在本例中是一个网站。我把它想象成一个很有个性、幽默、有锋芒的人。我希望它能将机智、聪明和愤怒结合起来，为女性——其中许多人被教导相信“女权主义”是一个坏词或一个应该避免的词——提供一种围绕性别和种族进行批判性思维的模式，这种模式让人感觉很容易理解和娱乐性。 As one of my colleagues, Moe Tkacik, ;wrote;, in an early post, “Jezebel is a blog for women that will attempt to take all the essentially meaningless but sweet stuff directed our way and give it a little more meaning, while taking [the more] serious stuff and making it more fun, or more personal, or at the very least the subject of our highly sophisticated brand of sex joke. Basically, we wanted to make the sort of women's magazine we'd want to read.”

;
;
;

;Of course, feminist Web sites and blogs were already exploring a new kind of politics among young American women.但是，与耶洗别不同，它们很少纳入强大且持续的流行文化分析，并且它们存在于互联网的外围。 (They also didn't have the funding and other resources that my staff and I enjoyed.) These sites, independently owned, with names like Feministing, Feministe, Racialicious, and AngryBlackBitch, had cultivated devoted readerships, but their audiences were small, and their language was often academic.

;

;Our audience, on the other hand, started off big and quickly got bigger, reaching more than ten million page views a month in the first year. (We had the benefit of being part of a larger blog network, anchored by ;Gawker;, which we would overtake in traffic in less than three years.) I was delighted, if a little taken aback, by our readers' immediate passion and loyalty.在网站推出后的两个月内，一些读者在网站的评论部分自发地称自己为“Jezebelles”或“Jezzies”。 Familiar screen names and avatars began to appear as regular readers populated the threads, talking with one another and, occasionally, with the site's writers.

;

;The majority of our commenters were very good.他们聪明、善于观察、博览群书、充满活力，而且有趣得令人眼花缭乱，他们为我们发表的故事增添了背景和细微差别，并敦促我们做得更好。 Within a year of Jezebel's launch, they even ;attracted; the attention of the New York ;Times;, which described them as meeting for drinks and renting vacation houses together.但有时他们也很糟糕：讽刺、卑鄙、思想上不诚实、互相欺凌。有时他们很可怕，表现得像一个扭曲的希腊合唱团，试图抢主要表演者的风头。 (Years later, as comments on Web sites began to migrate to social media, I would come to realize that they ;were; the main performers.) “That's sort of the nature of having a commenting community,” Erin Ryan, an early commenter who became a writer for the site, told me. “人们开始觉得他们应该对那里发生的事情有发言权。事实上，这不是出版物的运作方式。” At one point, in 2009, I toyed with the idea of handing the site over to the commenters for a day, just to watch them fail.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;At times we were accused of “tone-policing” our readers. And it's true: we ;did; tone-police, especially those commenters who were nasty or uncivil.我们会在评论中警告读者不要跨越某种界限。当他们破坏一条线索时，我们会要求他们将讨论转移到我特意命名为“群体思维”的每日随心所欲帖子的评论中。 （大多数评论者似乎没有明白这个笑话。）我本可以，也许应该，对他们更严厉。当时我的总编辑建议我将耶洗别视为我和我的作家举办的虚拟晚宴。 “你不允许有人对其他客人或主人如此粗鲁。你会把他们踢出去，”他说。 “在评论中做同样的事情。”但我们很少彻底禁止任何人。 No one wanted to punish readers for being impassioned.

;

;I like to think that, though the moderation was irritating to many commenters, it was also empowering.读者知道我们正在观看并且我们关心他们所说的内容。有人曾经告诉我，耶洗别的评论者虽然经常批评，但却非常热心，因为这个社区由聪明、雄心勃勃的年轻女性组成，她们在日常工作中没有得到充分利用和赏识。 I thought that this was a fascinating, if depressing, observation.

;

;I wondered, sometimes, whether my concerns about the comments were themselves sexist.我是否对女性有一定的行为标准？让事情变得更加复杂的是，我创办了耶洗别，并在我自己的愤怒的支持下使它取得了成功。 Though that anger, as I've explained, was legitimate and warranted—American women had been sold a bill of goods about who they were and what they wanted, or what they ;should; want—it was starting to define the site, for both readers and casual observers.

;

;I remember one blogger, a woman named Susannah Breslin, who, sometime after the site's launch, accused its writers of “caterwauling about the patriarchy.”这让我们笑了。布莱斯林指责《耶洗别》的编剧大喊大叫——呃，哇哇大叫——是有道理的。 We were not without mischievousness (our parent company encouraged a certain amount of snark), but we also leaned into our anger—about sexism, about racism, about the erosion of women's reproductive rights.

;
;
;

;Other critics accused us of intentionally stoking readers' outrage. In mid-2009, Slate's women's Web site, DoubleX, published, as one of its first posts, an article ;which claimed; that Jezebel “is hurting women.” “该网站的博主预计每天会发布大约 10 个高流量帖子，”女权主义学者 Linda Hirshman（本周去世）写道。 “博主们很快就意识到，吸引大量流量的一种方法就是向点击公众提供令人发指的行为。”她回忆起2008年的一个晚上，两名耶洗别的作家在接受脱口秀“思考与饮酒”的台上采访时喝醉了酒，并对性侵犯发表了油腔滑调的言论。 (These comments were then ;posted; on the Huffington Post for all to see.)

;

;I understood such hesitations—we had a big platform, and we were young and provocative and perhaps not ready for prime time—at the same time that I rejected them.在这种情况下，这种令人发指的行为并不是精心策划的，交通也不受欢迎。全体员工都受到了羞辱，我为此气愤了好几个月。 Less of an embarrassment was ;Tkacik's post; titled “Ten Days in the Life of a Tampon.” （标题概括了这一点。）我们很清楚这种令人作呕的故事可能会产生页面浏览量，但写这篇文章并不是为了吸引过多的关注，而是为了讲述一些真相——在这种情况下，是关于如何女性的身体确实在起作用。我不喜欢女权主义者监督其他女权主义者，尽管这种情况已经发生了好几代人。 And I wanted to think that we knew a little something about how to politicize a generation of young women—not by enforcement of doctrine but by example.

;

;Still, a story about Jezebel was emerging: that we were deliberately provoking our readers. In July, 2010, the writer Emily Gould ;published; a piece titled “Outrage World,” also at DoubleX, in which she accused Jezebel and other feminist blogs of cynically causing “firestorms” in order to boost page views. Gould went on to attack the site for exploiting “women's worst tendencies” by pushing readers “to feel what the writers claim is righteously indignant rage but which is actually just petty jealousy, cleverly marketed as feminism.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;When I look back at the piece, one thing is obvious to me: some of the firestorms that began on the site accompanied legitimately infuriating reporting.挑衅性帖子的主要例子是 2010 年 6 月的一篇报道，艾琳·卡蒙 (Irin Carmon) 在《每日秀》上报道了性别歧视，她后来在性骚扰和堕胎权方面做了开创性的工作。卡蒙与剧中的编剧、工作人员和一位前高管进行了交谈，他们描绘了一个受人喜爱、看似进步的媒体组织，实际上是一个男孩俱乐部。 (In 2017, Jon Stewart admitted, during an interview with Howard Stern, that she was right.)

;

;The other thing I noticed was that Gould, like many of Jezebel's critics, saw the writers as ;responsible; for the commenters: if Carmon's post provoked readers, then that was part of some master plan;如果评论者感到愤怒或残忍，这也是由该网站的工作人员设计的。在我编辑网站的过程中，我发现这些假设非常令人沮丧。事实上，每天都是在努力公平对待我们的评论者和确保群体文明之间进行谈判。 (Gould declined to comment for this piece.)

;

;When writing this, I remembered a ;2015 Jezebel piece; by Jia Tolentino called “No Offense.” In it, Tolentino, who at the time was the deputy editor of the site (and now is ;a ;New Yorker; staff writer;), tries to tackle multiple things at once, including how anger works on the feminist Internet and the ways in which digital media blurs the distinctions between readers and writers, creators and consumers. “‘这很糟糕’和‘你应该被冒犯’之间存在着巨大的差距，这似乎在互联网上消失了，我们越努力在这个网站上扩大它，我们就越被那种挥之不去的期望所束缚：耶洗别正如一些人一直想象的那样，它的存在是为了告诉女性什么时候应该生气，这是一种幼稚的目的，”她写道。后来，她补充道，“理论上，人们仍然期望女权主义网站能够告诉人们哪些事情会被冒犯；事实上，人们总是希望女权主义网站能告诉人们什么是应该被冒犯的。” but what people seek from a feminist site is that the site itself will cause offense.”

;

;I'm not sure that what people ;seek; from a feminist site is that it will cause offense.我认为他们寻找社区。但社区可能很困难——混乱、有争议、不和谐。 I recently came across a two-hundred-plus-page ;dissertation;, published in 2019, called “Architecture and the Record: Negotiating Feminism in the Jezebel Comments.”它是 。 。 。很多。作者梅丽莎·福布斯（Melissa Forbes）（再次！）指责该网站选择“迎合愤怒的女权主义者”。我认为她没有给予工作人员或我们的读者太多的信任。但《福布斯》的观察让我很感兴趣，这些评论纠正了该网站作者的女权主义。她写道，当作家们自己油嘴滑舌或残忍时，评论者就会提出“一种与页面上半部分不同的女权主义”。我对女权主义有“不同种类”的观点持异议，尽管它有不同的“浪潮”。但我确实相信，评论者对我们所做的一切的仔细阅读是他们建立社区的方式。他们互相学习，发展关系，发现自己的声音——即使他们（无论正确或错误）对编辑和作家感到愤怒，情况也是如此。 As one commenter quoted by Forbes put it, “I have learned a lot from the kinds of articles you publish on this website, and even more from your regular commenters.”

;

;That leaves the question of what, exactly, the Jezebel commenters had to do with the anger that exploded on social media. A few weeks ago, I spoke to the author and technologist Tobias Rose-Stockwell about his new book, “;Outrage Machine: How Tech Amplifies Discontent, Disrupts Democracy—and What We Can Do About It;,” which looks at the ways that enmity on the Internet is rewarded by social-media platforms, advertisers, and individuals.我告诉他史密斯的作品以及我对此的矛盾心理。 I explained that, though I detested accusations that we had used anger to manipulate readers, I wondered whether the outrage culture on social media had its roots in comments sections.

;

;Rose-Stockwell was not particularly familiar with Jezebel. （在他的辩护中，他不是目标受众的一部分。）但他回应了史密斯的主张，称网站上早期的两千条评论部分为“原始社交媒体”。 Sites like Jezebel, he said, were showing that it was “possible to bring people from passive consumers of news to engaged participants in the editorial process—something that was new for a media site.”

;
;
;

;In 2007, when we launched Jezebel, Rose-Stockwell explained, reader remarks could not be easily boosted or reposted.愤怒或冒犯行为仍然发生在社区范围内。然而，到了 2009 年，社交媒体——他称之为“舆论服务机器”——正在改变一切。 That year, he said, “three key features: ;algorithmic feeds;, ;social metrics;, and ;one-click sharing; fundamentally upgraded the speed at which we spread knowledge, propelling us into the modern viral era.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;In his book, Rose-Stockwell points out that virality did not emerge by accident.社交媒体技术人员使用情感语言对帖子进行优先排序。 These posts, in turn, can start “trigger chains”—in which social-media users are encouraged to react to inflammatory comments and “pick sides on topics about which we would otherwise have few opinions”—and cause “emotional contagion,” in which a person expressing an emotion leads to the “reflexive production of the ;same; emotion by others in the same proximity.”

;

;After I read this, I felt some measure of relief.我们在耶洗别上写的故事和主题并没有在某些有预谋的表演或操纵尝试中得到“服务”。它们是有机的。 ;They were the point;.我们不是抽象算法或“冲突企业家”（罗斯-斯托克韦尔书中的另一个有用短语，描述那些为了提升自己的形象而在网上制造或煽动混乱的人）。我们是有代理权和观点的年轻女性。我应该补充一点，我们也很有趣。 “我认为人们并不认可我们的幽默感，”前副主编多代·斯图尔特 (Dodai Stewart) 告诉我。 “我不想忽视一些更严重的事情，但是，从我的角度来看，我们的会议并不是我们坐在一起，每个人都涨红了脸，充满了愤怒和不安。大部分时间我们都玩得很开心。”前作家兼评论员艾琳·瑞安 (Erin Ryan) 更进一步。 “我不想生气，”她告诉我。 “我认为愤怒可以是伟大的。这是许多伟大的喜剧演员、作家和评论家的基础。我想说耶洗别是一个充满激情的网站。 But the passion wasn't necessarily just outrage for the sake of outrage.”

;

;In our conversation, Rose-Stockwell explained that he's not trying to condemn outrage so much as look at it from a more systemic perspective.无论是网上还是网下的愤怒，都让我们能够了解社会的问题，并共同努力开始解决这些问题。他说，它可以团结人们，并帮助社会围绕某些规范团结起来。从这个意义上说，对耶洗别的许多愤怒确实是富有成效的，为更大的政治和文化项目做出了贡献。 I think that one can draw a straight line from the feminist Web sites of the early two-thousands to a growing mainstream discourse around gender politics and race and patriarchy, from Beyoncé performing in front of a sign that read “Feminist” at the 2014 MTV Video Music Awards to the Women's March in 2017 and the explosion of #MeToo that same year to the recent juggernaut that is ;the Barbie movie;. (Yes, the Barbie movie. One of my former colleagues jokingly described the film as making her feel “like I was trapped in the Jezebel comments.”)

;

;A few weeks ago, I reached out to Smith and told him that I'd been trying to sort out the discomfort I'd been feeling in the wake of his piece.我解释说，当他说耶洗别是特定数字媒体时代的开始时，我需要他澄清他的意思。 What age was that?

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;“Social media,” he said. “That's how I think about it.”

;

;I pressed him. Was he saying that Jezebel influenced the ;tone; on social media, the conversation, or both? Did the site augur something that was brand new, or reflect something that was already in process?

;

;He replied that this was a question he'd struggled with while writing his book. “我觉得当我写作时，我总是遇到的问题是，X是否导致了Y，或者X和Y是否在同一条河流中被携带？” he said.

;
;
;

;I also wanted Smith to respond to my frustrations about that phrase “uncontrollable anger,” and the apparent ease with which he, knowingly or not, placed blame for the current political climate on outraged or opinionated women.

;

;He conceded that his phrasing might have been problematic or inartful. “I'm not trying to invalidate women's anger at all, but it does seem like that was part of the mix, and powerful,” he told me.

;

;“I think that anger was part of it, yes, but I don't think it was uncontrollable,” I replied. “I'd say it was ;very; controlled, actually, because that was the way women learned they should express it.”

;

;I see Jezebel not as the beginning of the end of the digital-media era but as a moment—a spark—within an ongoing discussion about gender politics.这次对话引发了有关性侵犯和性骚扰、薪酬不平等以及对女性的文化描述的新现实。这也让一些人感到不舒服，部分原因是女性以公开且持续的方式表达愤怒。 “Every woman has a well-stocked arsenal of anger,” Audre Lorde wrote in 1981, which can act as a “powerful source of energy serving progress and change.”

;

;If that's part of Jezebel's legacy, I'll take it.这就是我所希望的一切。 ♦

;Randy Fine is the only Jewish Republican in the Florida legislature, and has for several years been a strong supporter of ;Ron DeSantis;, the state's governor.法恩在 2018 年州长竞选期间担任德桑蒂斯的犹太外展主席，去年支持德桑蒂斯连任，并支持他竞选总统。然后，两周前，法恩决定将支持转向前总统唐纳德·特朗普。原因？反犹太主义。法恩认为，德桑蒂斯没有充分解决近年来在佛罗里达州发生的众多新纳粹游行。 (The ;Times; reported last month that DeSantis's unwillingness to condemn the marches has concerned some Republican donors at a time when his campaign is already lagging well behind Trump's.) The ;Hamas attack on October 7th; was the final straw.

;

;I recently spoke by phone with Fine to try and understand DeSantis's behavior, and why Fine was now turning to a man with a long history of using antisemitic tropes, and all-around bigotry. Our conversation, edited for length and clarity, is below.

;

;;A lot of people have come to support Donald Trump for different reasons over the years: the fact that he's a businessman, the economy, immigration. But you are supporting him in part because of your concerns about antisemitism. Can you talk a little about that?;

;

;Well, I was a big supporter of the President during his four years in office. 《亚伯拉罕协议》签署时我正在现场。我在白宫至少六次，所以我一直是他所做工作的忠实粉丝。 The fact that I had endorsed the Governor was not “I'm against Donald Trump,” if that makes sense.

;

;;Right, you had to choose, and so you chose, but you weren't—;

;

;I had been very unhappy with the quietness around the rise of Nazism.虽然我没有公开批评州长，但我私下里非常直言不讳，质问为什么我们不使用现有的法律。我们为什么不认真对待这个问题呢？ So were lots of his Jewish supporters.

;
;
;

;;And what was his response?;

;

;Well, the response is what you hear.我认为他一直非常稳定。我不知道这是否属实，但他说的是他不想通过谈论这件事来抬高他们。他质疑它们是否真实。他会说他们是假的，他认为他们这样做是为了让他难堪。 And he has said that consistently for eighteen months.

;

;;And you felt like you couldn't get through to him on that?;

;

;I couldn't, but the Nazis are one level of scary.

;

;;They are a high level for sure.;

;

;Look, I don't worry about these neo-Nazis executing the Holocaust in America.这很糟糕，我们需要对此采取一些措施。别误会我的意思。但哈马斯完全是“另一个层面”。于是，虽然我私下里不开心，但从10月7日起我就变了一个人。 And when I saw these protests break out within twenty-four hours in Florida, I knew that I had laid the groundwork by passing laws that could deal with this.

;

;;Which protests are you talking about?;

;

;There were pro-Hamas protests in Florida, in Tampa, and Fort Lauderdale.我开始意识到的另一件事是，如果唐纳德·特朗普当选总统，10 月 7 日就不会发生。 I would bet every dollar, because it didn't happen in his four years.

;
;
;

;;It's possible that October 7th didn't have to do with Trump, no?;

;

;The world was afraid of him.全世界都害怕他。没有人害怕乔·拜登，除非你是清洁楼梯的人。 No one's afraid of him.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;;Wait, what's the stair joke?;

;

;You know, he falls down the stairs.

;

;;Oh, I see. That's a good one.;

;

;In an era of darkness and blood, it is nearly impossible to remember that, from Moscow to Jerusalem, there was once a time of promise.不是决心，不是天堂，当然也不是历史的终结——而是承诺。 1989年至1995年间，发生了以下事情：柏林墙倒塌、东欧和中欧解放；苏联共产主义的崩溃和冷战（看似）的结束；北京和其他中国城市出现了短暂但令人震惊的民主运动；南非种族隔离制度的结束； and the signing of the Oslo Accords by the Israeli leadership and the Palestine Liberation Organization.

;

;In other words, in many nations, political leaders, dissidents, and social movements, having exhausted so many rotten ideas and endured so much oppression and tragedy, began to push the world in a direction of decency, democracy, and compromise. Of course, there is much that is oversimplified in that sentence—euphoria and triumphalism obscured some of the dark currents that persisted in those countries and in human nature itself—but the promise was real, and it ran deep.

;

;Now we live in ominous times, with Vladimir Putin's Russia laying waste to whole cities and towns in Ukraine, and the death count mounting in the Middle East.几乎每天都会出现新的更广泛的火灾威胁。普京会部署他的武库中最糟糕的武器，还是将他的军队扩展到其他前苏联加盟共和国？中东冲突会扩大到黎巴嫩、叙利亚和伊朗吗？只有铁石心肠的人才不会哀悼生命的逝去，并努力阻止它；只有傻瓜才会意识到未来更糟糕的日子的可能性。然而，绝望虽然是一种诱惑，但并不构成愿景。 2016年，当一位偏执的独裁者赢得了这个国家的总统选举时，绝望不是一种选择。 It is not an option now.

;

;It is almost a certainty, though, that, at least for some time, the forces of reaction, of furious radicalism, will persist.其中有两个生动的例子：最近，哈马斯高级官员加齐·哈马德宣称，以色列可能会遭受“第二次、第三次、第四次”袭击，直到它从地图上消失。 “我们必须消灭那个国家，”他说，“因为对于阿拉伯和伊斯兰世界来说，这构成了一场灾难。”在哈马德看来，没有必要为10月7日的暴行感到遗憾。 “我们不想伤害平民，但当地情况很复杂，”他告诉黎巴嫩电视台。 “我们所做的一切都是合理的。”与此同时，在以色列议会中，长期对西岸巴勒斯坦人进行可耻挑衅的激进定居者兹维·苏科特（Zvi Sukkot）被任命为西岸问题小组委员会主席。以色列当局此前对住棚节非常警惕，认为他不适合在军队服役。工党领袖梅拉夫·米凯利称他是“以色列最危险的人之一，是种族主义者、纵火狂和恐怖支持者”，有能力在约旦河西岸点燃“第二战线”。 (In the past, Sukkot was repeatedly arrested and expelled from the West Bank, on suspicion of committing arson and perpetrating violent attacks, which he denied.)

;
;
;

;The forces of hatred extend well beyond the region.联邦调查局局长克里斯托弗·雷在参议院作证时表示，美国的反犹太主义水平处于“历史水平”，并警告说，极端分子可能会从哈马斯“汲取灵感”，在美国领土上袭击犹太人。雷还表示，尽管犹太人只占美国公众的 2.4%，但他们却是“大约 60% 的基于宗教的仇恨犯罪”的目标。反犹太主义浪潮在欧洲可以说更为明显，德国总统弗兰克-瓦尔特·施泰因迈尔对此非常震惊，他在勃兰登堡门的一次集会上说，“犹太人今天再次生活在我们的恐惧之中，这是无法容忍的”。国家，所有地方。” And, as Rozina Ali writes in the ;Times,; fears of Islamophobic attacks in the Muslim American community are also on the rise; one of the more appalling examples is the recent stabbing death, in Illinois, of a six-year-old Palestinian American child, Wadea al-Fayoume, by his family's landlord, who, according to the boy's mother, shouted before attacking them, “You Muslims must die!”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Israel was created precisely out of a sense that a tiny and persecuted population, following centuries of violence culminating in the Holocaust, could no longer endure the precarity of exile. 10 月 7 日的大屠杀比以色列历史上的任何事件都更加粉碎了该国的保护意识。与此同时，加沙的巴勒斯坦人在经历了以色列多年的围困和封锁以及哈马斯的暴政之后，生活在极度的失落和恐惧之中。约旦河西岸的巴勒斯坦人继续生活在难以忍受的占领之下，这种占领最近变得如此恐吓和暴力，以至于人们经常谈论“第二次浩劫”的领土。如果加齐·哈马德和兹维住棚节等人继续发挥主导作用，任何建立安全和人类尊严的努力都将失败。 Any world in which Hamas and an increasingly reactionary Israeli leadership dictate the policy and the temper of the region is doomed to more injustice, confrontation, and death.

;President Biden's challenges are immense.面对可能针对日益狂躁的唐纳德·特朗普的连任竞选、俄罗斯对乌克兰的攻击以及中国的持续挑战，拜登还必须每天找到推动中东和平与安全的方法，同时鼓励中东地区的和平与安全。阿联酋、卡塔尔、埃及、约旦、沙特阿拉伯等复杂地区大国的积极参与。公开拥抱总理内塔尼亚胡并私下向他施压的标准做法早已被证明是一场无聊的游戏。自十九世纪九十年代以来，他一直致力于欺骗美国总统。 “我知道美国是什么，”内塔尼亚胡曾经说过。 “美国是一个你可以轻松移动的地方。”而且，那个自称为“Mr.”的人。 Security” presided over the biggest security failure in the history of the state.

;

;It may take years for a new political culture to take hold among the Palestinians and the Israelis.精神创伤可能需要很多年才能愈合。目前，对大多数人来说，谈论“两国解决方案”是怀旧的幻想，而“一国解决方案”则是立即发生内战的良方。所有的眼睛都因愤怒和悲伤而变得模糊，视力丧失就是现实。但是，正如巴勒斯坦学者萨里·努塞贝最近对我说的那样，“必须向人们展示或给予他们选择。我们没有悲观的选择。”至少灵感的一个来源是那个并不遥远的历史时代，当时的领导人和运动尽管有种种缺陷和失败，但一致同意，并为普通人自由、无恐惧地生活的权利而奋斗。这是一个在任何地方都无法完全实现的进程，但不能放弃到绝望的状态。 ♦

;On a Saturday in early fall, a sisterly crowd of political volunteers milled about in a community center in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.他们在那里帮助选举一位名叫苏珊·庄（Susan Zhuang）的三十七岁民主党人担任该行政区有史以来第一个亚裔占多数的选区（最近重新划分的四十三选区）的市议会成员。按照通常的情况，这个地区有一个复杂的轮廓，有几个急转弯。它大致像一只打鸣的公鸡，头顶接触着第八大道的凯丰福饺子馆，脚则栖息在本森赫斯特的海岸公园路犹太中心周围。 Voting for the seat concludes on November 7th.

;;;;

;Zhuang, who lives in Bensonhurst, grew up outside Shanghai, and came to the US when she was twenty.她形容自己对当地政治的了解几乎是偶然的。一位朋友请她送一盒茶给一位名叫威廉·科尔顿的长期议员。当她到达他的办公室时，她惊讶地发现有这么多人在等待他帮助处理各种问题——住房、食品券、社会保障。拥有 MBA 学位的庄自愿帮助低收入家庭和小企业纳税。 Eventually, she became Colton's chief of staff.

;

;Zhuang arrived late at the community center, in a pink campaign T-shirt and sneakers;她不得不在途中停下来拜访科尔顿的一位选民，他担心一棵垂死的梧桐树。 （“坑坑洼洼、路灯或需要砍伐的树木——任何东西——他们都会来到我们的办公室，”她说。）聚集在一起的志愿者准备巡查周围的社区，这是该地区一个充满挑战的地区，那里的居民以华人为主。居民对当地政治并没有表现出太大的兴趣。 “我想让亚洲人出来投票，无论你是否投票给我，”庄说。 “因为公众认为亚洲人不投票，所以亚洲人的声音并不重要。 We need to make sure our voice matters.”

;Seated at a table near the front of the room were three volunteers of high-school age.另一位志愿者向他们介绍了情况，她穿着佩斯利花纹连衣裙，搭配风衣靴，手腕上戴着念珠。 “每个人都必须记住，苏珊的第一政策是公共安全，”她告诉青少年。 “她支持警察，也希望监管电动滑板车。”庄插话道：“听着，他们很长一段时间都不想和你说话。如果他们这样做了，那么你就会提到更多。如果他们不这样做，请告诉他们苏珊是为了公共安全。” 2014年，就在庄开始为科尔顿做志愿者后不久，一名名叫梁彼得的华裔美国警察开枪打死了一名手无寸铁的黑人男子阿凯·格利，当时他正带着女儿在纽约东部的一个住房项目的楼梯间行走。尽管梁和纽约警察局坚称枪击事件是意外，但梁还是被判二级过失杀人罪。 （该定罪后来被降级为过失杀人罪。）该市的许多亚裔美国人，包括庄，认为梁已成为警察暴力这一更大问题的替罪羊。 “是的，他犯了一个错误，”庄说，“但很多警察没有被起诉。 When it's an Asian cop, they say he's a killer.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The volunteer in paisley assembled a canvassing group that included two teen-agers and two adults.孩子们都是所谓的测试学校的新生：乔安娜戴着眼镜就读于布鲁克林理工学院，而安娜则穿着史努比毛衣就读于史岱文森大学。 （这群人中的一位成年人是安娜的妈妈。）尽管庄强调公共安全，但她最出名的身份可能是主张保留特殊高中入学考试作为进入这些学校的唯一标准。亚裔纽约人在考试中表现出色：今年收到学校录取通知书的学生中有一半以上是亚裔。 （只有 3% 是黑人，大约 6% 是拉丁裔。）乔安娜说，她需要在大二结束时宣布一个专业，并正在考虑数学。她想进入当地一所好的大学，比如亨特大学。 “我只是不想负债，”她说。十四岁的时候似乎已经考虑了很多事情。 “I feel like it's a waste of my time to not think about these things, when I still have time to think about it,” she said.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Together, the group walked through the streets that thread Eighth Avenue.当一行人到达第一扇门时，乔安娜自愿带头。但没有人回答，所以他们又去下一个了。路上，乔安娜问安娜她在哪里上学，当她听到史岱文森学院时，她睁大了眼睛，这所学校和布朗克斯科学学院一样，可能是考试学校中最负盛名的。该小组花了三个小时进行游说，并与大约十几个人进行了交谈，但进展很艰难。 “中国人太残忍了，”乔安娜说。 “They just ignore you.”

;

;About a month earlier, near the jutting wing of the district, around a hundred people filled half of the restaurant New Choi Fook, which has the best price for king crab in Bensonhurst, at least according to one reviewer.人群在那里为庄的共和党对手谭鹰筹集资金。这位身穿红色连衣裙和白色高跟鞋的候选人解释说，她的竞选活动可以追溯到五年前，当时她开始为她三岁的大孩子寻找学校。 “有人注意到学校倾向于对我们不公平吗？”她问。 “We can't let people think that, as Chinese people, we won't speak up.”

;;;;

;Tan, who is thirty-two, grew up in Taishan, which has been called the “wellspring of the Chinese diaspora.”她现在住在皇后区的雷戈公园，并在她丈夫拥有的一家老年人日托中心担任志愿者。 Tan is a member of the New York ;Young Republican Club;;去年，她自愿参加了来自 Bay Ridge 的 61 岁前警察维托·拉贝拉 (Vito LaBella) 的州参议院竞选活动。他以微弱优势输掉了比赛。随后，拉贝拉和谭均宣布竞选新四十三届市议会席位。只有八百三十八人在共和党初选中投票；谭以三十一票获胜。但拉贝拉仍留在竞选中，坚持保守党路线，这可能会使陈的胜利之路变得更加复杂。为谭工作的政治顾问乔治·萨兰托普洛斯告诉我，他对拉贝拉的决定感到沮丧。在最近的一次共和党集会上，萨兰托普洛斯恳求他的党员向“中国选民、俄罗斯选民、宗教犹太选民”伸出援手，并补充道，“我很抱歉，如果我们想成为一个2023 年——我们的意大利朋友要搬到泽西岛，搬到北卡罗来纳州，他们已经去世了。 We have to get out of our comfort zone and reach out to those new voters.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The evening got under way, and a volunteer from Bensonhurst named Rosanne Li went to the front of the room. Like most of the evening's speakers, she spoke primarily in Cantonese, with English sprinkled in. Praising the diminutive Tan, she said, “You wouldn't expect someone with such a small”— switching to English—“body figure”—back to Cantonese—“but she has ;power;.”李试图解释为什么选举谭很重要。 “就在之前，当我走在八十六街时，我感到害怕，”她说。 “我和妈妈一起看到了一个”——换成英语——“无家可归”。她说她拍了一张照片，并列出了她看到无家可归者的其他地方。 She was worried that they would show up on her street, too.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;A member of the New York Young Republican Club's Asian Caucus, Nick Tan—no relation—sat with a family of constituents around a rotating array of steamed fish, Yangzhou fried rice, and other dishes.尼克在新泽西州长大，现在住在曼哈顿。 “民主党人，尤其是亚洲民主党人，并不代表我们，”他说。但是，在过去的两年里，他继续说道，“亚洲社区终于觉醒了，并做出了这种非常右倾的转变。”他坚称，亚洲价值观本质上是保守的。他对陈的共和党初选挑战者拉贝拉留在竞选有何看法？ “选民将控制党，”他补充道，“党的老板会喜欢我们吗？可能不会。”但他说，“乡村俱乐部的共和党人阻碍了世界的进步”，“他们将变得无关紧要。”亚裔美国人将成为共和党的新选民，而且将是一个强大的选民。”他对当晚的演讲有何看法？ “I forgot my Chinese a long time ago,” he said.

;
;
;

;Across the table sat a constituent in her late thirties named Liz Yang, whose family came to New York from Guangzhou.她的婆婆去了谭的老年日托中心。 “在成长过程中，我认为共和党是为富人服务的，而民主党是为富人服务的——如果没有这些政府福利，我的父母将难以抚养我们，”她说。但现在，她的很多朋友都是共和党人，她对两党的看法也发生了变化。 “他们不是在保护富人，”她谈到共和党时说，“他们是在保护那些真正赚到财富的人的财富。共和党想要保护中产阶级。民主党人希望让我们保持低收入。”她的一些朋友正从第 8 条住房搬进自己的家，她开始觉得政府的援助“让人变得懒惰”，她说。而且，它太复杂了。当她被解雇后，她申请了失业金，但这样做感觉就像是一份全职工作。另外，她正在为中风的父亲提供医疗保健服务。 “我真的希望我们的医疗保健系统像加拿大的系统一样，”她说。 “税收更高，而且机会均等，而不是我们的。” Ying Tan, like most Republicans, seems skeptical of nationalized health care: “You always have to watch when the government manages seniors' and retirees' health insurance,” she has said.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;After the fund-raiser, Rosanne Li stood outside the restaurant with her mother.两人都因这次活动而热闹非凡。他们同意，民主党正在毁掉这座城市。李说，例如，在学校里，孩子们正在接触同性恋。后来，她试图解释她对此感到担忧的原因。 “你知道我和我妈妈的关系有多好吗？我不希望学校向孩子们灌输同性恋观念——这会破坏孩子和父母之间的关系。家和家庭都会破碎，”她说。 “When I hear that some people who don't have a good relationship with their parents, whatever it is that caused them not to have”—she paused to think of the term, then switched to Cantonese—“a stable family, I don't want indoctrination to rock that stability.”

;
;
;

;The maître d' of New Choi Fook popped his head out of the door. “如果你要在外面聊天，不妨进来喝杯茶，”他用广东话说道。李夫妇感谢了他，但解释说他们要回家了。他们转身开始在高架地铁线下行走，一列 D 型列车在上方隆隆作响。 ♦

;;Plant Bee-Friendly Flowers;

;

;Lavender, sunflowers—you name it! Just make sure that whatever you plant generates tons of pollen, has a long blooming season, and provides its own welcome mat.

;;;;

;

;

;;Create a Bee Bath;

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Bees need a place to cool off, hydrate, and hear the latest buzz, like, “Sandra hatched her larva last week!” and “Did you hear the queen is hooking up with two dozen drones?”

;;;;

;

;
;
;

;;Raise the Minimum Wage;

;

;After all, that honeycomb won't make itself! A thirty-dollar-an-hour raise may initially shock a few downtrodden worker bees, but as honey consumers the least we can do is meet the bee union's demands.

;;;;

;

;

;;Build a Bee Home;

;

;First, consider the personality of each bee.大多数蜜蜂生活在装满各种空心管的小木箱里。然而，有些人更喜欢工匠小屋；有些人更喜欢工匠小屋。一些像牧场式的结构； and a select few desire a rococo-esque mansion with elaborate gilded interiors.

;;;;

;

;

;;Eliminate Productivity Quotas;

;

;Harvesting a huge amount of nectar per hour can cause mass burnout. Hundreds of exhausted bees are now unable to do anything but lie on the couch and binge-watch “The Masked Stinger” and “The Real Houseflies of Beverly Hills.”

;;;;

;

;
;
;

;;Hire a Teeny-Tiny Therapist;

;

;Because bees are very sensitive to vibration, temperature changes, and their emotional needs.

;;;;

;

;

;;Join the Protest;

;

;Who's got the power?蜜蜂获得了力量！加入他们反对掠夺性劳工行为的游行。 Display additional solidarity by boycotting bee predators, like bears and badgers and skunks.

;;;;

;

;

;;Sponsor a Vacation;

;

;No one can be a busy bee ;all; the time.他们在 PTO 期间会去哪里？维加斯？夏威夷？ None of your beeswax.

;;;;

;

;
;
;

;;Listen;

;

;If you're not sure how to help, don't be afraid to ask. Crouch down and get it straight from the bee's mouth.
